THE AIRSHIPR.101.Thanks andRewards, tothe French.Government..(previous reference:Cabinet 59(30), Con-clusion 2.)1. The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs informed the Cabinet that the British ambassador in Paris had reported that the French government wished to bear all the expenses incurred on Frenchsoil connected with the funeral of the victims ofthe disaster to the Airship R.101. The ambassador had asked for authority to thank the FrenchGovernment in suitable terms, and had submitted a number of proposals, of which the Secretary ofState gave particulars, as to Decorations, presentsto officials, etc., and to hospitals. The treasury were willing to allot the sum of 500 in all forthes e purpose es .While some criticism was offered in regard tothe proposals for Honours and presents, theCabinet agreed To authorise the Secretary ofState for Foreign Affairs, inconsultation with the british ambassador in Paris, to take'appropriate steps both to thankthe French Government and to distribute rewards and presents. THE LONDONUAVAL TREATY.rpfte Franco-Italianjjegot negotiations(previous oiisReference:Cabinet 43(gO), Con-elusion 2.,)2. The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs reported to the Cabinet the receipt of a telegramfrom the British Ambassador at Washington (No.343)setting forth an urgent proposal from the UnitedStates Government for simultaneous representations on similar lines by the Governments of the UnitedKingdom, Japan and the United States of America,to the French and Italian Governments in regard to naval construction. The occasion for this proposed action was the receipt by the United States Govern-ment of "pretty reliable information" that theFrench Government intended imminently to announce a building programme of three Battleships andanother 10,000-ton Cruiser, which would makeagreement with Italy still more difficult, and fromwhich, once announced, it would be difficult torecede.The proposal was that the three Naval powers should try to persuade the two Governments tobreak the present deadlock by each making a uni-lateral declaration that its programme during the lifetime of the Treaty would not exceed a level of"X" and. "Y" respectively.It was pointed out that the French appearedto have the right under the Treaty to constructthese ships, and that the three Governments concerned might expose themselves to a retort to this effect,although, of course, the French action was open tothe objection that they were building without previous agreement.The Cabinet agreed To authorise the Secretary of Statefor Foreign Affairs to associatein the action proposed if,after fuller examination, he deemedthis desirable. OIL FUEL SUPPLYAND CONTROL.The Productionof Oil from coal.(previous reference:Cabinet 47(30) Con-clusion 4.)3. On the proposal of the Prime Minister, thelabinet agreed (a) That the Secretary of State forAir should take the place of his predecessor in the conferenceswhich were entrusted to the lateSecretary of State for Air andthe President of the Board ofTrade, on behalf of the Cabinet,with representatives ofImperial Chemical Industries inregard to the wider aspects ofhydrogenation of coal, with aview to advising the Cabinet asto the policy to be pursued.(b) That the Secretary of State forAir should become the Chairman ofthe Oil Board. $EMPLOYMENT .(previous reference:Cabinet 59(SO), Con-elusion 12.)Public Works .Re-organisationof Industry.4. The discussion on Unemployment Insurance,for which the Cabinet had been called, was preceded by a discussion on the general question of Unem-ployment .The Chancellor of the Exchequer made a state-ment which gave rise to discussion on the followingpoints, among others:-PUBLIC WORKS.GOVERNMENT HELP IN RE-ORGANISING -INDUSTRY.THE STIMULATION OF WORK already decided ON TO RELIEVE UNEMPLOYMENT.EXPORT CREDITS TO RUSSIA.THE RESTORATION OF CONFIDENCE.In regard to public works- the cabinet recognised that the limit had almost been reachedof what could be done by co-operation with LocalAuthorities in relief works . While it would be undesirable to state this publicly, or to. discour-ag e any schemes that might come forward, it was apoint that the Government would have to bearconstantly in mind.In regard to Government help in the re^-organisation of industry, reference was made tothe action already being taken to press forward on the lines of the Cotton and Coal Reports of theEconomic Advisory Council Committees. The need was emphasised for finding credit for industry insuch matters as the urgently needed increase inthe size of coal tips at ports, and colliery screens,which were holding up the policy of substitutingthe 20-ton for the 10-ton truck. One suggestion was that some new organisation was requiredbeyond the ordinary Departmental machinery forsuch purposes. In this connection attention RUSSIA.ExportCreditsfor.(previous reference:Cabinet 54(30), Con-elusion 8.)PANEL OFMINISTERS .(previous reference:Cabinet 31(30). Con-clusion 3.)was called to the proposals of the Chancellor ofthe Duchy of Lancaster (CP.-283 (30)), which,it was suggested, were suitable for examination bythe Panel of Ministers.It was generally felt that some furtherstimulus was required in the matters referred toabove, as well as in carrying out the policy already decided on by the Government for the relief ofunemployment.It was suggested that a Minister should beappointed to co-operate with the President of theBoard of Trade in negotiations with the Bankers'Trust for the stimulation of suitable projects.The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs referred to a hitch which had arisen in ordersgiven by "Arcos", a British Company, but whosebills have to carry the counter-signature of theRussian Trade Delegation, - a matter which was seriously holding up trade with Russia.In view of the overwhelming pressure, duelargely to the Imperial Conference, on the time ofthe Prime Minister and several other members of the panel of Ministers, it was recognised that the panel would have to be re-organised if its activi-ties were to be sufficient to cope with the presentsituation.The Cabinet agreed -(a) That the Lord Privy Seal shouldsummon a very early meeting ofthe Panel of Ministers, whichshould be strengthened by theaddition of the Secretary ofState for War and the First Lordof the Admiralty:(b) That the Chancellor of the duchy of Lancaster should be summoned to attend meetings of the panel of Ministers: (e) That the Panel of ministers should take up the various questions mentioned in theabove Minute, including thedifficulties in regard to russian Credits, on whichthey should consult theSecretary of the Departmentof Overseas Trade:(d) That the First Lord of theAdmiralty should co-operate with the President of theBoard of Trade for the purpose eof negotiations with theChairman of the Bankers' Trustwith a view to stimulation ofindustrial organisation andfinancial credits required forsuch purposes as those mentionedin this Minute.(See also the following Minute.) mjEMPLOYMENT0SURANCE.-(previous reference:Cabinet 60(SO), Con-elusion 12.)5. The Cabinet had before them the Memorandumby the Minister of Labour (CP.-318 (30)) on thesubject of Unemployment Insurance, which had beenunder consideration at their last Meeting, referredto in the margin.The Prime Minister proposed that thequestion should be remitted to the Panel ofMinisters, and he expressed a strong hope thatthe question of abuses, even though they werelegal abuses, would be faced boldly. NeitherParliament nor public opinion -was likely to besatisfied merely with the appointment of a royal Commission to enquire into these matters.The Cabinet agreed --To refer to the Panel of ministers the proposals set forth inparagraph 16 of CP. 318(30). agricultural policy.Reconditioningof Land.(previous reference:Cabinet 55(50), Con-clusion 1.)The Cabinet authorized theMinister of Agriculture andFisheries to enter into discussions with the Chancellor of theExchequer in regard to a proposal made by Mr. Lloyd George to acquire and for reconditioning,with a viewto an early report to the Cabinet onthe subject.- 8 - INDIA.Appointment0f Vicerdy.(previous reference:Cabinet 60(30), Con-clusion 5.)7, Tbe Prime Minister informed, bis colleagues of the name which, after further discussion, hadcommended itself to the Cabinet Committee for theappointment of Viceroy of India. He asked thatthe utmost secrecy might be preserved in thismatter. EXPORT OF ARMSARE AMMUNITION.Aeroplane forBrazil.(previous reference:Oabinet 57(30) Con-clusion 12).8. Tickers had none in stock and had asked if the Royal Air Force could releaseto them some of their machines of this type to be replaced as soon as possible.In view of the recent cabinet decision on this subject, the Secretary ofState for Foreign Affairs offered noobjection.On the understanding that the price would cover the cost of replacement, theCabinet agreed To approve the above proposals.-- 10 THE AIRSHIP 9.
